text: Doing FPS that way is the wrong way. In professional game development we use a timer not to limit the cycle rate unless you are using vsync. Vsync sucks. What you effectively did was create a vsync and turn it on. except it isn't hardware based on video refresh rates or anything. If you want all your stuff to move at the same rate on different machines us use the timer to determine how far they moved each frame. So for example if you want something to have a velocity of 60 pixels a second you time how long it was from the last cycle with your timer. If you do it in milliseconds you divide the time the last cycle took by 1000 then multiply it times the 60 so you know how far it should have moved in that time. Then you update the position to that.   It also doesn't guarantee 60 FPS or cycles. It just limits you to that being the max. So if someone is running slower hardware their entire timing is going to be off any ways. All it does is cause the system to burn up CPU cycles if it gets around to that point and 16.6 milliseconds haven't passed by.  On modern hardware you are better off creating your own timer using int(round(time.timer() * 1000000) so you can get the microseconds. clock.tick() returns in microseconds. which can be to slow for modern hardware. text: I looked up the flip and update issue, and it turns out that update, with no arguments passed, is the exact same thing as flip. However, you can pass arguments and use update() to update only a portion of the screen. So you can use flip to update the whole screen slightly faster (no argument checking) and if you only need part of the screen to change you can use update() and pass that portion of the screen.

author: @Jono997
text: For anyone who's frustrated with the fact that the programming is bound to the frames per second, there is a workaround. Have two threads, one for all of the background tasks and one for updating the display. The background thread should take care of all the programming and the display thread should just update the display. Have the background loop's clock.tick = the number of times you want the background tasks to be handled per second (typically 1000) and have the display thread's clock.tick = you actual FPS. If you wanted to ensure that the display thread wouldn't output an incomplete frame, there is a way to do that, but I don't know how to put it into words, so I won't.
